questions.title: Passage Ⅰ
questions.article:
Agarose, a carbohydrate composed of galactose subunits, is found in the cell wall of some types of algae. Agarose can be broken down by the enzyme agarase. A student discovered a new form of agarase, Agarase X, in a species of bacteria. The student conducted the following experiments to determine the temperature and pH at which agarase X has the greatest activity.

Experiment 1

The student added 0. 2 mL of an Agarase X solution to each of 9 test tubes (Tubes 1-9), and then added to each tube 0.8 mL of a buffer solution (a solution that maintains a stable pH) having a pH of 7 and containing 0.2% agarose. Each of the tubes was incubated at a different temperature for 30 min, and the relative activity (percent of the greatest measured activity) of the Agarase X was determined for each tube (see Table 1).


Experiment 2

The student repeated the procedures used in Experiment 1 in every respect but the following: the test tubes (Tubes 10-18) received different agarose buffer solutions, each of a different pH, and all the tubes were incubated at 40°C. Once again, the relative activity of the Agarase X was determined for each tube (see Table 2).
questions.question: 1.  Which of the following factors differed between Tubes 10 and 18?

choices.A: The temperature at which the tube was incubated
choices.B: The volume of liquid added to the tube
choices.C: The pH of the agarose buffer solution added to the tube
choices.D: The concentration of agarose in the agarose buffer solution added to the tube

Once again, the relative activity of the Agarase X was determined for each tube (see Table 2).
questions.question: 2.  Suppose Experiment 2 had included an additional tube, which received an agarose buffer solution having a pH of 2. The relative activity of the Agarase X in that tube would most likely have been:

questions.question: 3.  Based on the results of Experiments 1 and 2, the optimal temperature and pH for the greatest Agarase X activity are closest to which of the following?

questions.question: 6.  To best determine the pH that results in the greatest Agarase X activity at 60°C, the student should:

choices.A: repeat Experiment 1, but incubate all the tubes at 60℃.
choices.B: repeat Experiment 1, but add an agarose buffer solution having a pH of 10 to each tube.
choices.C: repeat Experiment 2, but incubate all the tubes at 60°C.
choices.D: repeat Experiment 2, but add an agarose buffer solution having a pH of 10 to each tube.

questions.title: Passage II
questions.article:
Students performed 2 experiments to study plant pigments.

Experiment 1
The students crushed spinach leaves in a solvent, forming an extract that contained the pigments from the leaves. The extract was spread in a straight line 2 cm from the bottom of a piece of paper. After drying, the paper was placed in a tank containing a second solvent, such that the bottom of the paper was immersed in the solvent and the line of extract was above the surface of the solvent (see Figure 1).


Each pigment in the extract had a different degree of attraction to the solvent in the tank and a different degree of attraction to the paper. Consequently, as the solvent in the tank moved up the paper, the pigments moved up the paper at different rates. The extract separated into 4 bands each containing a different pigment (Pigments S, T, U, and V), as shown in Figure 2.


At 60 min, the paper was removed from the tank. Next, the distance traveled by the solvent was measured (63 mm), and the distance traveled by each pigment was measured (see Table 1). Then, the Rf, value for each pigment was calculated using the following expression:



The Rf values are also shown in Table 1.



Experiment 2
Each band was cut out from the paper and then soaked for 24 hr in a separate beaker containing 50 ml of a solvent. A sample of the solvent was then removed from each beaker. The absorption spectrum of the pigment (the relative absorption of light by the pigment over a range o wavelengths) in each sample was determined (see Figure 3).
questions.question: 7. Chlorophyll b is a pigment in spinach leaves that absorbs light most strongly at 450 nm and 640 nm. Based on the results of Experiment 2, which pigment is most likely chlorophyll b?

questions.question: 8. According to the results of Experiment 2, at which of the following wavelengths was the relative absorption of Pigment U greatest?

questions.question: 9. Suppose that in Experiment 1, a fifth pigment had been present in the spinach extract. If the Rf had been 0.25, where would the pigment have been located on the paper?

choices.B: Between Pigment S and Pigment T
choices.C: Between Pigment U and Pigment V

choices.A: distance traveled would have been longer.
choices.B: distance traveled would have been shorter.

questions.question: 12. Which of the following statements best describes Experiment 2?

choices.A: The bands were cut out from the paper, 1 pigment was extracted from each band, then the absorption spectra of the pigments were determined by analyzing each extract.
choices.B: The bands were cut out from the paper, 1 pigment was extracted from each band, then the absorption spectra of the pigments were determined by analyzing the paper.
choices.C: The pigments were extracted together from the paper, then the absorption spectra of the pigments were determined by analyzing the extract.
choices.D: The pigments were extracted together from the paper, then the absorption spectra of the pigments were determined by analyzing the paper.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
Students in a science class determined the lengths and volumes of solid metal objects having various shapes, compositions, and temperatures.

Study 1
The students completely immersed a cylindrical brass rod in a water bath that was open to the atmosphere. Over the next 10 min, they maintained the temperature of the water bath at 20°C. After the 10 min had elapsed, the students used a micrometer to measure the rod's length, in centimeters (cm), while the rod was still in the water. Next, they increased the temperature of the water bath to 40°C, waited 10 min (while maintaining the water bath's temperature at 40°C), and again measured the rod's length. Similarly, they measured the rod's length at 60°C and at 80°C (see Table 1).


Study 2
The students completely immersed a metal cube in the water bath. Over the next 10 min, they maintained the temperature of the water bath at 20°C. After the 10 min had elapsed, they measured the length of each of the cube's sides while the cube was still in the water and then calculated the volume of the cube, in cubic centimeters(cm3). Following the same procedure, they determined the volume of the cube at 40°C, 60°C, and 80°C (see Table2).


Study 3
The students obtained cubes composed of different metals, each cube having a volume of 125.00 cm3 at 20°C. Following the procedure used in Study 2 for determining the volume of a cube, the students determined the volume of each cube at 60°C (see Table 3).
questions.question: 13. Based on the results of Study 1, if the temperature of the cylindrical brass rod had been decreased from 40°C to 20°C, would the length of the rod more likely have increased or decreased, and by how much?

questions.question: 14. Suppose a student repeats the procedure used in Study 1, except that the length of the brass rod is measured in 10°C intervals. At 30°C, the length of the rod will most likely be closest to which of the following values?

questions.question: 15. The purpose of the water bath was to：

choices.A: promote the formation of a thin layer of oxidation on the surfaces of the metal objects.
choices.B: ensure that the metal objects would float.
choices.C: regulate the temperature of the metal objects.
choices.D: regulate the atmospheric pressure to which the metal objects were subjected.

questions.question: 16. Which of the factors listed below was (were) the same for all cubes tested in Study 3? I. Composition of cubeII. Initial volume of cube III. Final volume of cube

questions.question: 17. A particular bimetallic metal strip consists of a bottom layer and a top layer, each layer composed of a different metal. When heated, the strip bends upward (see the figure below). Suppose the strip has a bottom layer made of copper. Based on the results of Study 3, to make the strip bend upward when heated, the strip's top layer should be made of which of the following metals?

questions.question: 18. Based on the results of Study 2, the change in volume of the metal cube, △V, in cm3, due to a given change in temperature, △T, in °C, is given by which of the following equations?

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article: The total magnification provided by a compound light microscope is determined by multiplying the power (magnification) of the ocular lens (eyepiece) by the power of the objective lens. The area seen when looking through a microscope is called the field of view (FOV). The diameter of the FOV varies with total magnification. Table 1 gives the power of, and the FOV diameter associated with, 4 different objective lenses on a microscope (Microscope M) with an ocular lens power of 10x. Table 2 lists 4 types of microscopic organisms found in pond water and gives their size ranges and their distinguishing characteristics.
questions.question: 19. Suppose a student wants to use Microscope M to view an organism. Which objective lens should the student first use to locate the organism, and why?

choices.A: Objective Lens 1, because Objective Lens 1 has the lowest power, resulting in the largest FOV.
choices.B: Objective Lens 1, because Objective Lens 1 has the highest power, resulting in the largest FOV.
choices.C: Objective Lens 4, because Objective Lens 4 has the lowest power, resulting in the smallest FOV.
choices.D: Objective Lens 4, because Objective Lens 4 has highest power, resulting in the smallest FOV.

questions.question: 20. Which of the organisms listed in Table 2 have the largest size range?

questions.question: 22. A student needs to examine an object through Microscope M using a total magnification of 400x. Based on Table 1, which objective lens should the student use?

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article: The total magnification provided by a compound light microscope is determined by multiplying the power (magnification) of the ocular lens (eyepiece) by the power of the objective lens. The area seen when looking through a microscope is called the field of view (FOV). The diameter of the FOV varies with total magnification. Table 1 gives the power of, and the FOV diameter associated with, 4 different objective lenses on a microscope (Microscope M) with an ocular lens power of 10x. Table 2 lists 4 types of microscopic organisms found in pond water and gives their size ranges and their distinguishing characteristics.
questions.question: 23.  The figure below shows an organism viewed through Microscope M using 1 of the 4 objective lenses. The organism is the largest specimen of its type. Based on ables 1 and 2, which objective lens is being used to view it?

questions.title: Passage Ⅴ
questions.article:
The higher a gasoline's octane number (ON), the more smoothly the gasoline burns, lessening engine damage. Sulfur (S), naturally present in gasoline, damages exhaust systems in cars. Table 1 gives the ON and S content of 6 gasolines (Fuels A-F).


Figures 1 and 2 show the decrease in ON resulting from using Methods 1 and 2, respectively, to reduce a gasoline's S content from a given initial value to a given final value. Consider a gasoline having an ON of 90.00 and an S content of 100 ppm. If Method 1 is used to reduce the S content to 25 ppm, Point A in Figure 1 shows that the decrease in ON will be 0.35, so the ON will decrease to 89. 65 (because 90.00 - 0.35 = 89.65).
questions.question: 24.  Consider 3 gasolines having S contents of 50 ppm, 75 ppm, and 100 ppm, respectively. According to Figure 1, if Method 1 is used to decrease each fuel's S content to 15 ppm, the decrease in ON for each fuel is best shown by which of the following graphs?

questions.question: 25.  A car manufacturer claims that the lowest ON of a gasoline that can be burned in a certain engine without causing damage to the engine is 88.00. Which of the gasolines listed in Table 1, if any, should be burned in the engine?

choices.B: Fuels A, B, and D only
choices.C: Fuels C, E, and F only

questions.question: 26.  Suppose a chemist used Method 1 to reduce the S content of Fuel D and of Fuel F each to 10 ppm. Based on Table 1 and Figure 1, after the reduction, which fuel would have the higher ON?

choices.A: Fuel D, because the ON of Fuel D would be about 91 and the ON of Fuel F would be about 86.
choices.B: Fuel D, because the decrease in ON of Fuel D would be less than the decrease in ON of Fuel F.
choices.C: Fuel F, because the ON of Fuel D would be about 86 and the ON of Fuel F would be about 91.
choices.D: Fuel F, because the decrease in ON of Fuel D would be greater than the decrease in ON of Fuel F.

questions.question: 28.  Fuel A was formulated by using Method 2 to reduce the S content of another fuel, Fuel Z. Based on Table 1 and Figure 2, before Fuel A was formulated, if the S content of Fuel Z was 75 ppm, the ON of Fuel Z was approximately what value?

questions.title: Passage Ⅵ
questions.article:
Two solid spheres, X and Y, have the properties listed in Table 1 below.


The spheres are simultaneously released just below the surface of the water in a large container (see Figure 1).


Three students make predictions about which sphere, if either, will be first to reach the bottom of the container.

Student 1

The net downward, force on a sphere, Fnet, equals the weight of the sphere minus the strength of the buoyancy force exerted on the sphere by the water it displaces. The sphere that has the greater Fnet will reach the bottom first. The strength of the buoyancy force on a sphere equals the weight of the water displaced by the sphere. However, because both X and Y have small volumes, the strength of the buoyancy force on each sphere will be much less than the sphere's weight, so the buoyancy force will have little effect on how fast the sphere sinks. Thus, due to Y's greater weight, Y will sink faster than X, and Y will reach the bottom of the container first.

Student 2

After the spheres are released, gravity will cause each sphere to accelerate until it reaches its terminal speed, vt, the speed at which its weight equals the frictional force retarding its motion. Because v, is proportional to the square root of the ratio of a sphere's mass to its radius, and because the ratio for X is equal to the ratio for Y, the spheres will reach the same vt. However, because Y has more mass than X, Y will have the greater acceleration, so Y will reach vt first. Therefore, because Y will fall faster than X until X reaches its terminal speed, Y will have the greater average speed and will reach the bottom of the container first.

Student 3

Because the gravitational acceleration of a falling object is independent of the object's mass, X and Y will have the same acceleration. Moreover, because the ratio of mass to radius for X is equal to the ratio of mass to radius for Y, the spheres will reach the same vt. Therefore,X and Y will have the same average speed and will reach the bottom at the same time.
questions.question: 29.  According to Student 2, vt is proportional to which of the following expressions?

questions.question: 31.  A weakness in the discussions of the 3 students about the effects of different forces on the spheres' motions is that none of the discussions takes into account the:

choices.B: total effect of gravity and friction.
choices.C: total effect of gravity and buoyancy.
choices.D: total effect of gravity, friction, and buoyancy.

questions.question: 35.  Based on Student 1's discussion, for Fnet on Y to equal zero, the strength of the buoyancy force on Y would have to equal:

questions.title: Passage Ⅶ
questions.article: In the ionosphere (the atmosphere between 50 km and 2,000 km above Earth's surface), gaseous atoms and molecules lose electrons and become ions when struck by energetic solar radiation (X-rays and ultraviolet radiation). The figure shows the electron density, in free electrons/cm3, for a portion of the ionosphere above a 45°N latitude location. The electron density and the specific ions present in the D, E, and F layers of the ionosphere are important in the long-distance transmission of high frequency radio signals. Electron density varies between daytime and nighttime as well as between maximum sunspot count and minimum sunspot count.
questions.question: 36.  The greatest electron density plotted in the figure corresponds most closely to which time of day, which sunspot count, and which altitude?

choices.A: time of day         sunspot count             altitude (km)    daytime                maximum                       290
choices.B: time of day         sunspot count             altitude (km)    daytime                minimum                        320
choices.C: time of day         sunspot count             altitude (km)   nighttime               maximum                       290
choices.D: time of day         sunspot count             altitude (km)   nighttime                minimum                       320

questions.question: 39.  Before being struck by solar radiation, gaseous atoms and molecules in the ionosphere are electrically neutral. After they are struck, are the ions that are formed positively charged or negatively charged?

choices.A: Positively charged, because the gaseous atoms and molecules lose electrons, which are negatively charged.
choices.B: Positively charged, because the gaseous atoms and molecules lose electrons, which are positively charged.
choices.C: Negatively charged, because the gaseous atoms and molecules lose electrons, which are negatively charged.
choices.D: Negatively charged, because the gaseous atoms and molecules lose electrons, which are positively charged.

questions.question: 40.  Locations that receive more direct solar radiation typically have greater electron densities in the ionosphere above them than do locations where solar radiation is less direct. The ionosphere above a location at which of the following latitudes most likely has greater electron densities at every altitude than the values given in the figure?
